reviewText: I bought this DVD since Linda Darnell has always been a favorite of mine.  I was pleasantly surprised how much I enjoyed the film and the performances.  The biggest surprise was an almost flawless print FOX has released.  FOX's track record has been pretty inconsistent with their archive releases.  Its doubtful if restoration was done so the print quality was most likely in great shape.  Highly recommended.
summary: DARNELL A STAR OF THE FIRST MAGNITUDE
Title: N/A

reviewerName: D. S. Wymore "Golden Age of Hollywood fan"
reviewText: Star Dust is a Hollywood story that perpetuates the myth that any girl with some talent can become a movie star over night - or so was the case of it's star Linda Darnell.This film has often been called "Her Own Story" because it mirrors what happen to Linda Darnell in real life. She was a teenager in Dallas when she was "discovered" by a 20th Century Fox talent scout. Unfortunately, Linda didn't have the happy ending (in real life) that the film has.The basic plot: a teenager is discovered by a Hollywood talent scout but then he changes his mind, after he discovers she's still a teen. Carolyn (Linda's character), wheedles her way to Hollywood by by-passing the man and going straight to his boss. Once she's on her way, she meets other recruits, one of which is handsome John Payne. An assortment of mishaps happen along the way and soon Carolyn is on her way back home but the supporting cast manages to get her back to Hollywood and on her way to stardom.I think one of the best scenes is John Payne singing (his own voice too!), "Secrets in the Moonlight". Mary Healy sings the Hoagy Carmichael classic, "Star Dust" and Charlotte Greenwood is the character she's so good at playing. Roland Young (best known as "Topper") is the talent scout . Look for future Fox star George Montgomery in a small part.I've had this film for years as a taped from TV VHS tape so I'm happy that Fox has finally released it. It was never available on commercial VHS.I have one rule about buying any of the Fox Cinema Archives DVDs - if I own it on VHS tape, I'm not going to buy the DVD. This is because the DVDs offer nothing more than the VHS tape did. So, unless the tape breaks or my VCR dies, I'm buying the DVD only if I have the film taped from TV or if I never had any copy.No extras of any sort: no chapter index, no glossy inserts, no commentaries, etc.LInda Darnell did become a movie star at 17 but many sad circumstances lead her in bad directions and she became a has-been at the age of 30. Sadly, she died in a house fire when she was in her early 40s.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is the story of several youngsters seeking fame in Hollywood.It's a long hard road to the top, but Linda Darnell, John Payne,Mary Healy, Mary Beth Hughes and George Montgomery give ittheir best shot. Roland Young and Charlotte Greenwood are therefor support and to pick up the pieces for those who don't make it.The title song is sung by Mary Healy and played throughout.Secrets In The Moonlight, Sagebrush Sue and Don't Let It Get You Downare all very hummable tunes.Fox Cinema Archives have released a beautiful black and white film on dvd.I really think it looks about as good as it gets.There are no extras.
summary: Linda Darnell - a star is born!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Old musicals are such a favorite of mine. Older professional actors & actresses are, too. I like this just because of this. The storyline went smoothly with Linda Darnell & John Payne in the leads. Linda was not the 'hot siren' role that often she later played. Here she was just a normal & contained young lady looking to better herself with her love for singing professionally. John was the male lead that eventually became a heart interest of hers & vice versa. It was B/W but not a problem for this older lady.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've longed to see this movie for many, many years.  Though released finally in the DVD-R format, I will be the first to say I am far from disappointed!  Fox's Cinema Archives presentation, while bare bones, does boast a surprisingly beautiful restored picture.  The transfer is lovely, on par with some of the best Fox has offered in their pretty much defunct catalog DVD releases.Linda Darnell was a miracle to behold on-screen. She had the presence of someone much older than her years.  Obviously Fox saw this as a unique opportunity to build a picture around her screen stardom.  Its tragic they were so willing to dump her from their roster just a decade later.Interestingly, this was allegedly the picture Linda Darnell was watching on TV the night she died in a fire in 1965.Easily worth the price!
Title: N/A
